reviewText: Warlock is a turn-based strategy game similar to Civilization series with a fantastic world view, full of sorcerers, elves, orcs and legendary creatures. In a nutshell, it is the fantasy version of Civilization but a bit simpler and easier. The player plays the role of a mighty mage, ordering your people to build cities, construct facilities and recruit army to expand your territory. Just like Civilization series, there are many different routes to achieve victory. The player can occupy a specified portion of the world, cast an ultimate unity spell, or conquer all of the other mages to win this game.\nBut There still are some fine features makes it pretty different from Civilization. Firstly, the player study powerful spells in this game instead of technology in Civilization. And differing from other magical games, the player can not only cast combat and healing spells, but also many powerful auxiliary spells to raise the land up beyond the sea level or fertilize the land. Besides, the combat unit the player can recruit needs a upkeep expense, thus limiting the number of army to smaller scale. This mechanism save me much time in mid to latter stage of gameplay. Also from time to time some legendary heroes with special ability might come to seek the opportunity of servicing you, though the expense of hire and upkeep is amazingly huge. They might also turn to service other mages and become your nightmare if you decide not to hire them. And don't forget that you are a mighty mage. You can cast powerful spells to interfere the war when your troop are engaging your rivals on the frontline.\nAnyhow, if you don't have much time to play a whole campaign in other grand strategy games like Civilization and don't want the gameplay to be as complicated as Civilization series, Warlock might be a good choice then.

reviewText: Certainly found this game to be an enjoyable strategy game - it felt like playing some Civ games, but with two big differences that I saw: the portals allow you to travel to *other* worlds - which is pretty cool.  You end up trying to expand beyond your current map through portals into other worlds, all while continually building up your war machine.  The other difference was the ability to cast spells on the map - this means healing units, destroying enemies, etc.  I like games which give a sort of macro-game like this on top of the Civ hex strategy model.  Definitely an enjoyable game, but I don't know that I would recommend it as the paragon of its genre.

reviewText: Essentially the fantasy version of Civilizations, Warlock is a game that is easy - and criminal - to overlook.  Possessed by a surprising levity to match itself with the common run of modern fantasy parodies, but not nearly as overbearing about it as most, Warlock is a game of many subtle pleasures and joys.  The interface is more accessible than Civ, there is virtually no micromanagement, and there are very few turns of empty waiting for researches to complete or diplomatic tensions to crumble: the world is always larger than it seems and there are always scarier monsters lurking in the wings, protecting prime real estate for colonization.  I have no qualms about calling it the most exciting, entertaining, and most streamlined turn-based strategy game I have ever played.  It lacks some of the sophistication and depth of Civ or the Total War franchise, but it makes up for it in sheer playability.

reviewText:
This is a fantasy themed modification of Civilization V. Some of the same core mechanics are here; research, city building, army building, war and combat, leader traits and multiple paths to victory. Resource management, commerce, trade and diplomacy are also here, but are heavily simplified and limited compared to Civ V's mechanics; land management and building management have been combined for example. This game is geared much more towards war and combat.

Wonders have been replaced by Gods who grant rewards based on your favor with them. Technology is replaced by magic spells, but magic spells do not operate like technologies do in Civ V. Magic spells require mana and time to cast and do not provide civilization wide changes like technologies do. Most magic spells provide only small changes to the game such as damage to all units in a small area, the summoning of a unit or the raising or lowering of land and are not as important to the game as technologies are to Civ V.

The Civ V religion system is gone, there are no great people and many other mechanics of Civ 5 are gone as well. Some of the unique additions to the game are quests that randomly appear and grant rewards upon completion, 'Heroes' which are powerful units that can be purchased or found and Temple units which are powerful units granted by Gods. As said earlier, this game is geared towards war and combat and most of the additions to gameplay reflect that.

It's built on Civ 5, a solid and widely enjoyed game. In turn, it is a solid albeit simplied game that many would enjoy especially if war and combat is what you enjoy most in Civ 5.

reviewText:
Personal Rating: Great Game, balanced, addictive and features rich.
Classic Rating: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†

I loved it from the first match - which i lost :)
As you know this is a fantasy turn-based strategy game: what i liked most is the great variety of mages (lords), troops (from humans to goblins to undead), monsters (snakes, bats, wolves, bears) and spells (elemental, arcane, attack/defense, healing/blessing), at your disposal.
You are never bored, even when you have to wait some turns in order to gather your resources.. moreover, the game HUD offers a truly good aid telling you which actions can be taken at your turn (build, research, attack, trade or diplomatic affairs).

The game automatically saves your match (you can save by yourself anytime, though); gameplay is basically one single battle against one or more enemy mages, over one or more worlds, till you achieve the victory or die trying. Multiplayer is supported too but i haven't tried it yet.
IMHO, one thing could have been done better: tutorial and general guidance through the game when you play it for the very first time: it's not that easy to be ready to go but the learning curve is not that high either.. once you start exploring menu and icons you get the feeling on what is what and how things work.

Strongly recommended, you can't miss Warlock: Master of the Arcane.

reviewText:
Warlock:Master Of Arcane
Admired for it's simplicity, Warlock:Master of Arcane is just that 4X Turn-Based type of game that keeps you hooked for hours and hours.
The 4X sub-genre of strategy games scares away all but hardcore strategy fans and the infinitely patient. Basic things, like combat and resource management, may be familiar to RTS fans, and the turn-based nature won't bother RPG fans. However, the level of micromanagement and diplomacy can be overwhelming for newcomers who aren't familiar with the likes of Civilization and Master of Orion. Paradox saw how difficult it would be for new players to jump into a popular 4X strategy game and offered help with Warlock: Master of the Arcane, a strategy game that seems designed to ease players into the genre.

Interestingly, the game gives the player no real backstory. From the online instruction book and the description on Steam, you know that the lands of Ardania (from the Majesty game series) have been chaotic since the last king died over 70 years ago. The gods feel that the time is right to appoint one of the High Mages as the next ruler. With seven mages vying for the role, your job is to have that mage obliterate everyone else and take the throne.

Rating: 8.5/10

reviewText:
The spiritual successor to Civ 2: Test of Time's Fantasy Game Mode that Firaxis likely will never give.

The game basically plays like a Civ game with a fantasy mesh. A Civ 5 game ofcourse, but a Civ game nonetheless, only there is actual difference between the races in the game in how they operate at the most basic of levels.

There's Human, Undead, Elves and Monsters and they all work differently.
Each race has different units, though they do share some specific units and they all also have a few unique buildings, but share mostly all the same ones.

Humans are balanced, because uncreativity.
Undead eat Mana and are really good for taking out neutral cities early-game.
Elves are powerful and can research Spells the fastest.
Monsters can produce more food than any other race, meaning more cities earlier on.

The game doesn't suffer from any Arbitrary systems that people have grown used to and grown to accept, such as Happiness, Culture, Religion or Tourism. There's none of that. Instead every building and every unit requires some form of upkeep. Some requiring food, or gold, or mana, or two of those, or all three I think.

Instead of following a rigid as crap tech tree, you only research spells, which are situational abilities that cost mana. you accumulate it overtime like gold, and spend it on these spells, and the spells range from creating temporary units, damaging or buffing existing ones, or even altering spaces on hte board, like making more land. Yes, one spell turns ocean into land.

reviewText:
First Glance (~2h played)

Take the old classic Master of Magic, mix with Civ5-like terrain and UI, throw in a hint of HOMM and add decent if not great AI. What do you get?

- You get racial specific, balanced units which can be buffed or upgraded.
- Lots of fighting between Mage armies, minor cities, monsters. This is the main focus of the game.
- There's lots of units, and you dont depend on one race, only start with one.
- Only three races, but at least they're balanced and there's a boatload of indipendent units.
- Simple spell research in place of tech.
- Ability to unleash said spells to modify units, terrain or cities.
- Simple but honest Truce, Pact or War diplomacy.
- A world to explore and expand upon. Then another world when you find a portal link to it. And another one after that...
- Guarded loot as in MoM, monster spawners, rampaging monsters, and other map features to keep exploration interesting.
- Some spells are fire&forget, others are buffs that require upkeep.
- Simplified economy. Few resources to manage, all directly related to keeping your war machine on the march and growing.
- Slightly convulted way in which buildings unlock other types of buildings or even troops.
- Very little terrain feedback! (Archery bonuses, terrain defense, etc).
- Oceans that are worthless except as passages.
- Pumpkins as a resource on which Shrines of the Rotting Pumpkin can be built. ikr, awesome!
- Resources that grant bonuses or allow for units to be built in the city.
- AI that can fight. (turn up the difficulty)
- AI that ... will occasionally attack Ghosts (weapon immunity) with a common melle unit (uses weapons). Genius, but doesnt really work.

Also:
- Gods, ability to anger gods, and become destroyed by angry gods.
- Multiplayer, so you can throw fireballs at your friends like they were pies!
- A dose of humor, as the game doesn't take itself too seriously. Unit responses and even unit names can be humorous.

Between Master of Magic, Civ V and Heroes of Might and Magic, Warlock mostly resembles MoM, but with tactical combat replaced by Civ's system. Why did i not know of this game before? Granted that it's not one of the best ever made, but it's very good and can favorably be compared to Civ V (IF, and that's a big IF, you want the game simplified and focused on combat). I think the name is stupid, that's probably worth 10% of a review score right there.

reviewText:
This game is amazing.
First off if you were lucky you got this game for free, if not it goes on sale for less than $5 everytime.
The first thing you will realize is that it is a civalizations type game.
It starts you off as one of 12 (might be more) different wizard lords bound to their own cause, but free to become your own.
Instead of having pesky villagers you have to worry about dying, you have city extensions that produce resources and other bonus wonders.
You should play this like you play Sid Myers Civ 5, and you will be fine, but in case you need it there is an in depth tutorial that doesn't bother you or drag on forever.
Instead of advancing to the next stage in technology like most strategy games this keeps it cool and stays in the same era of weapondry, which is one thing that bugged me when playing the Civ Games. There is nothing more lorebreaking like seeing the Myans with robots nuking and anchient Chinese Empresses.
The game has a large variety of units and has a large focus on casting badass spells if you have the mana.
The enemy wizard lords AI lacks a large variety of negotiations, but at least you wont have Ghandi yelling at you for being a Warmongrel.
FInally, and at long last, I would say this is a very fun alternative to Civ 5 and is significantly better for the low price.
8.75/10 Good job Ino-Co, I'm hooked.

It was a solid effort but something was missing.  Warlock re-treads this ground in Wizardâ€™s robes and does it quite well.  It has the tight and balanced combat of the PG series with plausible and clever (role based) fantasy units brought from several traditions.
The Bonus to me is that there is as well a generous layer of Civ-5 era Civ-type flavour heaped on.  Research tree, Religious favour, building wonders (sorta), and cultures with distinctive units all have their place in the overall game play and strategies.
This game may not have the most original ingredients but it has taken the right amount from each of itâ€™s influences and mixed them well.
Although I like this game quite a bit, I do have some complaints:
- There does seem to be a memory leak where one needs to reload the game every few turns to prevent processing slow down.
- The underworld's populations seem to grow exponentially out of control by mid-game.

Overall I would recommend this game to gamers who are any flavour of strategy enthusiast or specialize in turn-based-strategy, hex war games, fantasy strategy or are looking for fantasy/strategy options away from the main stream.
- Overall: 8/10.
- Tighten up the scripting: 9/10.

Absolutely brilliant fun. I got this free from Humble Bundle the other day (September 2014), and played it for the first time expecting just to have a quick look and then leave it for ages. But I'm still playing my first game, and it's still excellent.

If you've ever played Civ you'll be right at home. Age of Wonders and Eador fans (among others) will also appreciate it for the fantasy armies. It's nice and easy to get into, everything is very intuitive and not over-complicated. Polished interface and detailed, crisp graphics, and a nice variety of SFX for what it is.

Negatives? Well, at this early stage I might call it 'lite' strategy, although so far the AI has been robust and interesting and it's clear that this, like Civ and AoW etc, is a long-haul experience. Really, there's nothing to dislike just yet.

I ended up getting this game for free through a website promotion.

You don't need workers to build stuff for you, your city automatically does it based on sufficient population of each city. Absolutely brilliant fun. I got this free from Humble Bundle the other day (September 2014), and played it for the first time expecting just to have a quick look and then leave it for ages. But I'm still playing my first game, and it's still excellent.

If you've ever played Civ you'll be right at home. Age of Wonders and Eador fans (among others) will also appreciate it for the fantasy armies. It's nice and easy to get into, everything is very intuitive and not over-complicated. Polished interface and detailed, crisp graphics, and a nice variety of SFX for what it is.

Negatives? Well, at this early stage I might call it 'lite' strategy, although so far the AI has been robust and interesting and it's clear that this, like Civ and AoW etc, is a long-haul experience. Really, there's nothing to dislike just yet.

Excellent strategy game that's all about conquest, leveling up your units to ridiculous levels of power and supporting them with all kinds of spells. Best dev support ever: since game release they've added Multiplayer, heroes, artifacts, a better UI, terraforming and in DLCs, a new race and the new Armaggeddon game mode.

The demo has not been updated with those features so it won't give you a correct idea of the game.

While people who don't have much of a strategy game culture will compare this to Civ V, developer Ino Co have been masters of hex-based strategy games for a long time, with Fantasy Wars (http://store.steampowered.com/app/63900/) and the Elven Legacy (not on Steam for the moment as its publishing deal ended) series. They basically took the kind of gameplay they know well how to do and added Age of Wonders-like spell research and city management. There is no tech tree, complex diplomacy, cultural trees, no real research besides random spell picks or any of those Civ trappings, it's mostly about warfare.

My only complaints would be that the AI is not evenly challenging and that endgames can verge on the boring when you know you have the power to crush the enemy but sieging cities takes forever. And don't leave your cities unguarded, as some random events spawn powerful creatures behind your lines.

All in all though, highly recommended. Looking forward to the sequel!

Best way I can describe this is Civ V meets Warcraft III.  If you're a fan of the genre, might as well give this a look, especially since how easy it is to get it on the cheap.\n\nMight I add it's just as addicting as Civ and games will take a while.  No real instant gratification here.

At first glance, this game is like Civ 5. A fantasy version of Civ 5. A half-done fantasy version of Civ 5. I was wrong and right at the same time.

This game - as I just said - is pretty much a Civ 5 clone at first glance, however later on you learn that this game is not quite. With game mechanics that parallel them, this game still has plenty of other ideas, concepts and such which are completely different. The first that springs to mind are the spells.

Spells are either the worst thing you in the history of ever or the best thing ever. Depends purely on which side you're on. These are an interesting - though unsurprising - element added to the game. Their near unlimited number and their wide range of effects can basically make you god-like, however these spells require mana and time to cast and if they are ongoing spells, mana for upkeep. However if you have tonnes of mana and little gold, fortunately you can just have the mass of your army be summed creatures that simply require mana for upkeep rather than gold (Some require both. Awesome...)

An unusual set of elements are artefacts and lords. They randomly come about throughout the game and can be purchased/hired so long as you have enough gold to afford their upfront cost. Although you can find them in the map at various locations, I seem to find them a lot more of them to purchase at the start of the turn. The lords are a lot like their common unit counterparts, however with unique perks and abilities with the ability to equip artefacts to them to change or add more abilities. One lord got my attention and stood out from all the rest. It is - and I'm not making this up - the infamous rabbit in Monty Python and the Holy Grail. I have screencaps of it if you don't believe me. The funny thing is about this creature is that it is one of the most OP units in the game Arm the rabbit with a broomstick and it can fly, crossing all terrain with no movement penalty and the ability to take on any creature. However there are stronger lords beyond this one so [OP intensifies].

The game also has pocket dimensions and they are randomly scattered through the map (supposing you have enabled them) and are infinitely useful once you managed to capture one, drive out all the late-game monsters and in general wrestle them under your control. However once one is under your control, you essentially increased the power of your empire without the further need to war with other Great Mage (players or if you don't have friends like me, the CPU). Even then, if the wars do happen, the other Great Wizards are going to go through hell to reclaim any pocket dimension.

The communication and interaction with the Great Mage is fairly limited compared to those in Civ 5, with no request there being something that can have a minor result if you decline. If someone either demands resources from you or has a request, declining it can either result in outright war with the other Great Mage or destroying your alliance if it's a request. It would be great if declining wouldn't be so extreme and would simply just decrease the Great Mage's attitude towards you rather than... this. Another thing that bugs me is that either there's no option to request a war with another Great Mage or I've missed it entirely.

The same applies with quests. These are also unusual game mechanics that at some times can be VERY ANNOYING! Why? Failing to complete a quest can result in a punishment. Usually they don't amount in much e.g. some gold/mana lost, but some can be kinda... dumb. For example, one god losing favour with you simply because you couldn't build a church in time. For that to happen, you need to get yourself some holy ground and if that's in anothers' land, you have to go forcibly take it from them. Something like that isn't usually done in a small space of time. Taking a city can take many turns, even with a decent, strong army. Fortunately, some quests seem to last forever so you have plenty of time to do that quest. Unless you forget the quest and do other more presssing matters at hand.

Overall, Warlock is a pretty good stratergy game but could do with a bit more effort towards the interaction with other Great Mages and a bit of rebalancing with their lords.

reviewText: Solid for a budget title but could have been great if they fleshed out some of the non-combat mechanics -- this undercuts three of four of the victory conditions making 'domination' the only relevant/interesting choice (and then it is simply a matter of capturing the rival capitols). When Warlock was first released it seemed to me to be a disappointingly shallow 4X with diplomacy that only seemed to be in the game so they could say it was there and an annoyingly random research system.

All credit to the developers they have been adding content to the game with free patches which have since added more depth, character and even online multiplay. They have done enough to raise my estimation of the game to the point that I would actually recommend it.

For me, Warlock is the perfect after work slice of strategy gaming. Where Modern Manshoot 5 is just to brainless and Complicted Inaccessible Grand Strategy is too complex. Warlock sits in a comfortable niche of being accessible but thoughtful.

It's not the sort of game you'd lose a weekend to though.

reviewText: I enjoyed this game a lot. D&D meets Civilization. The only thing that frustrates me is that the spell research seems very random.

Usually I try not to make arbitrary comparisons, as one-liners are often not enough to explain intricate games. In this case though, I thought it might help some niches weigh off choices. Warlock takes the best element of Civilization V, namely hexes that enhance strategic gameplay. It takes the best of Civilization IV with its deities and random events. And it takes the best of Civilization Revolution, which is the much faster pace, without toning down the experience. It leans the most on the latter and is most reminiscent of fantasy title Master of Magic, but without the lighter aftertaste. Take that as you will.

This game is truly magnificent! it's a turn-based 4X strategy / RPG-ish game in the style of the Civilization series. Yet it focuses more on action / combat & RPG-like unit leveling / upgrading, less so on civil management - it's the perfect balance between city building, resource economy & combat / leveling.

The spells, heroes, unique items etc are great fun, practical & make expanding / progression both rewarding & engaging. Graphics look great & gameplay is solid & intuitive. Good tunes too.

You basically assume the role of a Great Mage, build / manage an army & expand your kingdom while battling other Great Mage's, doing (or failing) quests given by various Gods - which determines a reputation rating - casting spells that rain down AOE fire-balls upon your enemies from the safetly of your castle or summoning creatures to your aid - this game has it all!

It's a great system all round, gameplay is fun & the mechanics instill a sense of progressive growth. It's a truly satisfying, visceral experience.

So much fun!

reviewText:
For someone like me who prefers Real-time strategy games, playing Warlock - Master of the Arcane was a very pleasant experience
I had played Civilization V before and I liked it. But for some unfortunate circumstances I couldn't get it on Steam, so I settled with this one. Turns out this game wasn't that different from Civ V, all the core elements are there, with the addition of a fantasy setting, mythological units and the ability to research and cast spells.
The goal of the game is simple enough, all you need to do is to defeat the other mages in the map. To do this, however, you need to manage your cities and resources, expand your empire, explore the game's world and capture important resources, research the right spells that match your strategy, and guide your troops and upgrade them. On paper it doesn't seem different from a RTS game, but the turn-based system is a bit more tricky. Unlike RTS games, it does not emphasize on micro-management, but careful planning before making any move and having a strategy.


The game has some optimization issues, the story is non-existant and the game could get a bit repititive if you don't know what you're doing. But it's still worth every penny (and seeing how the game is on sale all he time, it won't cost you much anyway)
I say it's a decent alternative if you can't afford Civ V, and a good start if you want to give this genre a try without spending much on the other more famous titles.

reviewText:
This is one of those games that can very easily put off first time players, with no tutorial and an extremely complicated layout that doesn't look at all user-friendly. I was indeed one of those people who was put off, so left the game alone for quite some time. But i decided to give it another and while it still took a whie to get to grips with it, i finally discovered that the game is actually fairly straightforward.

This game is made by the same team who brought us the the Majesty series... visually it looks quite similar, and in terms of sound is extremely similar, thanks to the same bloke doing the voice over as he did in the Majesty games (so yes, it is the same awful Sean Connery impression). Thankfully, for those people who hate the butchery of the Scottish accent, he doesn't speak nearly as often as he does in any of the Majesty games.

Given how they introduced their own unique slant on the RTS genre with Majesty you'd be forgiven for thinking they would do the same for the turn-based strategy genre here, but this time they haven't and stick with the popular turn-based formula that fans of the genre will instantly recognise. This is by no means a bad thing.

Once you get past how complicated the game looks and get just half an hour of it under your belt, you'll be hooked. It's well worth persevering with as this is a great game that is certainly deserving of your time. It's also frequently included in Steam sales, so is often available at a bargain price. Pick it up during a Steam sale and you won't be disappointed at all.

reviewText:
Civ 5 with wizards.

You have 3 resources, gold, food and mana. You use mana to maintain enchantments and magical units, as well as cast spells. Food goes to supporting cities and units. Gold goes to building and army upkeep, as well as buying new units.

It's simpler, but still crazy addictive. There are also 'Lords', basically hero units that require a lot of upkeep but can equip artefacts and are essentially more powerful than standard units. Seriously, if you pile the enchantments on, these guys can get ridiculously OP, it's so fun.

There's a religion system, where you do quests to earn favour with gods that govern particular spheres (such as death, strength or the sun). At first I thought, oh great, another list of made up deity names for me to learn, but there's not so many and they all make sense. It's especially easy to remember as they have polar opposite gods as well, e.g Dauros is the god of order and law, his rival is Fervus, god of chaos and nature.

I'm not a massive strategy fan and I love this game. Fans of the 4X genre might want something more complicated, but this is a worthy buy for me.

reviewText:
Civ meets RPG/Fantasy.

Really fun 4X.

Imagine you could cheat in Civ, yet it was balanced, that's Warlock. Each round, based on your mana pool, you can cast spells that influence your units or other aspects of gameplay. From increasing your food supply to levitating your infantry units so they can pass over the water.

The different races have a different play style too and benefit from different priorities. If you capture cities owned by other races however, some of their unique perks can be supplied to your units. Vampires with Silver Weaponry? Why not!

You can even build a multi-cultural army later on, so you're not overly hindered by your initial choices.

I give it about an 8/10, just a few annoying glitches here and there (if you alt-tab out to use the internet, you get massive keyboard lag). A lot of the smaller icons Would benefit from a null space behind them as if you misclick slightly you can give out orders you did not intened to.

But minor gripes. Very good game.

reviewText:
The game is a TBS similar to Fantasy Wars and Elven Legacy.

Good things:
Dozens of different and varied spells
Dozens of building types
Dozens of unit types
Bad things:
No campaign or story mode. Only skirmishes.
Lots of bugs
Dumb AI
Random mob spawning
Some spells are overpowered
The game is fun, but has too many downfalls to enjoy for long. My biggest concern is that the enemy player AI is really easy to beat. They don't have a strategy, they don't match attack types to defence types, and they randomly proclaim peace or war. Even on the hardest difficulty they're easily beaten.

To compensate for the lack of difficulty, the game introduces random mob spawnings. The strength of these mobs seem to be random, so it's very possible that you get wiped out early in the game by a mob spawn. They can spawn anywhere and at any time, which makes it hard to create a strategy to defeat an opponent. Even worse are the Dremer, who also spawn with gates and contimate the lands. This gets really tedious after a while since there's nothing you can do about the spawning, and they just serve to increase the game difficulty in an obnoxious way.

Another thing are the spells. You can resurrect any unit, but not always a hero. You can lower the land and put tough enemy units in the water, making them easy to defeat. You can cast mana drains on your enemies or erupt vulcanoes on their lands. This severely debilitates them, but they never apply these tactics to you. So after some time, the gameplay becomes the same. Slowly advance towards the enemy while dealing with the random spawns until you kill all. It gets tedious after a while, which is a shame as I really wanted to like this game.

reviewText:
This game is not a Civ5 clone!!!

With that out of the way, what exactly is Warlock then? The resemblances are so similar it looks like a cheap knock off, but is it? I am happy to say that the answer is no. While there are some similarites between both games, warlock focuses purely on war.

You build military on a seperate queue from regular buildings, you have no workers to manage, no happiness to keep positive and by extension no luxury resources, everything you see and find is for war.

You can win by owning most of the land, or researching the ultimate spell, or capturing all capital cities. Don't these victory conditions sound familiar? The only problem is, you will never have a game that lasts long enough unless you intentionally drag it out to achieve any other victory except a war/domination victory.

This game begs for multiplayer, which thankfully it does have! The netcode is pretty okay too. The downside? No simultanious turns. You cannot take your turn (or seemingly do anything) while your foe takes their own turn which means that games drag on way too long! This is a game about war, I have a large military to move every single turn and so do my foes! This limits multiplayer to 1v1 because large groups are not going to finish a match in a day.

Warlock is fun, the mechanics are engaging, the lore is rich and humourous in places and playing 1v1 with a friend is very stimulating. If I could rank a game as neutral then this one I would. But I can't so I can't recommend this game.

One last thing, enemy AI. They are brain dead. You can win games by simply leaving the AI alone long enough to die to wild monsters. I am not even joking. They have no concept of how to play the game and certainly no idea of how to win it. If you played Civ5 and thought the AI there was bad, then that AI will seem like HAL from a space oddysey after you have seen the bone-headed bizaare AI that this game offers. The wild monsters (barbarians) are more of a threat than the actual opposing leaders.

reviewText: Don't see what all the fuss was about. Game is super boring. First off, there is no tutorial, just a few hints, so nothing to describe convoluted interface, all the mechanics, the upkeep, resources, how everything works, etc. Then there is no campaign, just running skirmishes on similar levels with similar opponents against the computers. There are tons of inconsistencies that don't make sense. Why for some reason if you attack can you not move after, that makes no sense. If I can move then attack, why can't I attack then move, like with archers, it's called retreating.....it's called battle tactics, look it up. Then sometimes I will run out of movement and be right next to a guy, but it won't let me attack them because it says I am out of movement......well I am just attacking him I don't need to move, so that makes no sense. Sometimes you can move past guys on squares, sometimes you can't. Then the action is dumb. Sometimes you lose a ton of your units sometimes you lose like nothing, and you can't get a good idea of what will happen. The gameplay isn't fun either. You have no clue how much your guys can move without moving them on the board. It will sometimes not tell you if you have a guy with moves left in a turn. You spend 2/3 of the time ending turns and waiting. Your guys only move like 2-3 spaces per turn, meaning they can't do anything.  You can build 1 single building every like 5 turns and it takes 4 turns to build. Guys take like 3-4 turns to be produced. You build up mana and everything so slowly you can cast a spell once every 30-45 min or so, and the computer can cast tons of spells. Also how fast mana and food and everything comes is not explained and you have no idea what your production is at. It takes forever to kill a single group of people and especially a little town or village. I spent like 2 hours in 1 small circle area and nothing happened. You only get basic boring units for the first few hours, like archers, swordsman, a ship, a bat, and a caravan. It was so uninteresting and uneventful and slow I finally had to call it quits. If you want to spend 2/3 of your time in a game ending turns and accomplishing nothing until 15 hours, then this is the game for you. reviewText:
So many tiny things that are messed up that could have made this game great.

1. Units have no auto explore. This has been a part of 4x games since Civ 3 I think. It is absurdly frustrating and time consuming to have to literally click on every unit every turn.

2. Clicking: WHY did you not use both the right and left mouse buttons? It's insane. The clicking over a unit to then do all actions with the same button is very frustrating and often leads to multiple clicks to get one action done. Also click zones are very tiny and leave you inching your mouse to get the right thing.

3. Minimal control of your economy and tech tree. Basicly you have no input onto what is happening. Should I build more gold or more mana collectors, who knows. Oh I'm suddenly bankrupt, but wait, it has no effect because the next turn I'm fine. WIthout some kind of feedback into your economy/techtree the user is very disconnected from the guidance of their own civ.

4. On that same note, you elminated so much of the users investment in their character by nutering the character design. I know this is just a reskinning of Master of Magic so I'm not expecting anything groundbreaking, but by removing the faction aliance to life/death/fire/air/etc you took away the special feeling of a character growing and learning a certain type of magic for a certain philosophy. Now all characters are bland and seem to take magic from all schools.

5. Never ending enemy spawn. Now I get that this is a core part of the game but it's also unnecessarily frustrating. As a builder I want the sence that I'm taking over this land and making it safer/better for my people. What's the point of me having magic walls around my cities if skeletons, vampires, and cheap humans just suddenly appear. On the same note they really don't do anything to you except attack your cities again and again and very rarely can they beat your cities ability to heal, essentially making them just a nusiance.

6. Oh last but not least, Users CAN'T SKIP ACTIONS! I don't care if some random village was built and I don't care if a sea monster is swimming past my capital. I should not have to bomb every enemy that walks by. I should have the choice.

Overall I cannot recomend this game. The reskinning of MOM is long awaited and the graphics for the most part are great, though many buildings are difficult to distinguish adding another minor frustration. This game was almost good but overall I say skip it.

reviewText:
Overall description:
In short: If you like other turn-based strategy games, you will like this one as well.

Things it has in common with other turn-based strategy games:
Randomly generated maps.
Everything is on hexes.
Growing cities.
Settlers that build new cities.
Negotiations with other Warlocks.
Warships for sea battles.
etc...
This this game does differently, compared to other turn-based strategy games:
The city upgrades are visible on the map, but can't be destroyed by enemies.
You can build Forts and Magic-towers that, along with the city, can fire on nearby enemies. These two buildings can be destroyed.
Each unit and hero takes up one hex on the map, you can't combine them.
Each ground unit turns into its own transport ship. The ship disappears when they land.
You can cast offensive, defensive, and even map-changing spells.
There are alternative worlds that you can raid.
Constant random map events.
Not overly complicated.
etc...
At first, some people will feel weird with each unit taking up on hex, but you get used to it and actually learn to like it. As your troops and heroes level up, get more upgrades, and become stronger, you learn to value each unit and want to keep them alive.

You research spells and harvest mana to cast them. Each spell has a mana cost, but there is also a limit on how much you can use per tern. Spells will use up a small part of what you can use per turn, a big part, all of it, or even take several turns to charge.

Some of the most fun I had in this game:My enemy had a large fleet of ships that wanted to invade me. I held the beach with three melee groups, one archer group, and a healer hero that had a healing aura passive ability.
I was destroying his ships before they landed and bottlenecking anything that landed. A lot of spells were used and a lot of people died... it was glorious! The guy offered resources and begged for a non aggression pact after I held the line.
In another game, I kept trying to assault a guy, but I got pushed back several times because I was outnumbered. I lost a lot of heroes and a few really upgraded units. In my last push, I sacrificed two really good heroes and took two cities. Then I built forts and mage-towers between those two cities to draw the border line. I help it with Stubborn Knights, two groups of heavily upgraded Elven archers, a healer hero, a flying Elven boat, and two groups of druids. After holding the line and devastating the enemy capital with spells, all the land was cursed and filled with tentacles from all the spells. I devastated his army and blew up his capital city... I loved it.You don't really get moments like that in other games. In Total War, you have something similar during the RTS, but it's a lot more fun with spells blowing things up everywhere and randomly appearing armies.

If you decide to get this game, be warned:The game is not very well optimized and there are a few bugs. The game may crash and may even freeze your computer.

There are typos and it's clear that development was abandoned, but it's a fun experience. I got the game from a pack for 1$, but it may be worth buying when it is on sale.

reviewText:
Warlock is Civ V fantasy knockoff that ends up being an interesting blend of the elements of RTS into the TBS formula. It is  unfortunatly marred by poor AI. The game attemts to make up for this by spamming monsters to add to the difficulty. Rather than solving the problem, this simply makes late gameplay tedious and  emphasizes the incompetence of the competing mages. Overall, not a horrible game, but there are better games you could spend your time on.

Why you should buy it:
*Civ style fantasy game.
*Strong tactical element.
*Unique city building and unit treatment gives an RTS/TBS hybrid that has potential.
*Competent graphics and polish.
*Steam cards.

Why you should avoid it:
*Little or artificial difficulty.
*Shallow and tedious gameplay.
*Poorly implemented magic system.

reviewText: Yesterday I finished a match with 4 mages (1 me 3 cpu) on Large map with 3 underworld maps. It took me 12 hours, victory by conquering. Although in here instead of research you have spells (that can be powerfull) and on the first plane are not towns and civilization - but heroes. reviewText:
The easiest comparison is Civilization 5 with magic. Alright, review over, that was easy!

Okay, really though, it LOOKS like Civ5 at first - it's a city-building game with hex tiles and units that don't stack - but it actually works fairly differently. To explain:
1: There's a whole lot less focus on cities. In particular, there's not even a research tree! Each city instead has a progression of buildings it can produce and... well, to avoid getting into details, let's just say that every city is just going to specialise in producing one resource and it's nearly always obvious what to build next. It's very simple compared to Civ5.
2: On the flipside, there's a whole lot more focus on military. In particular, constructing units does NOT slow down constructing buildings, instead costing their own resource (gold) to produce. And there's always wild monsters of varying toughness to kill. The end result is that, rather than in Civilization where peace is the most beneficial option, in this game EVERYONE has an army!
3: Spells. There's a LOT of spells, and they do a lot of stuff - from hurting and healing to buffing and nerfing to summoning units to changing the landscape to, hell, there's even city-wide buffs in this game. Spell research is what takes over regular research in the Civ games.

This is all leaving out the other big details, like heroes and gods and the nifty way you get better units. But that could go on for a while. And it's got some problems of its own because it lacks polish, things like a point where micromanagement gets annoying, and that you can't turn off animations (although you can skip them every time), and there's no synchronous multiplayer turns which it so desperately needs. The lack of polish is why I'm really looking forward to Warlock 2.


But the short of it is: I really like it! On it's own, it's really not as good as Civilization 5, it just didn't have the budget to be. But if you love playing super-aggressively in it, this is a game made all about that!


Oh, as for DLC? Elves adds a new race focused on research and Armageddon introduces a rather nifty man-vs-monster mode, so they're both great. And the rest... isn't worth it. Although really, if you haven't got the game yet, you should just get the Ultimate Edition, it's definitely worth the extra cost!

reviewText:
A game full of promise and potential ruined by exceptionally brain dead AI, poor interface, the occasional bug, and features that make the game waaaaay too easy.

Everyone seems to love Warlock. I'm not sure why. Once you know the ins and outs of the game, there's nothing to it and it becomes very boring and uninteresting. Occasionally the AI opponents will declare war on you for no reason. Occasionally monsters will randomly spawn in your territory for no reason. Often times there's zero threat and even on the harder difficulties, these messes can be cleaned up easily. Its less fun and more annoying than anything else.

Warlock is in desperate need of more variety. For game that comes across as a fantasy version of Civilization, it instead chooses to ape Warcraft 3 making for a weird turn based version of it. Ripping off Civ would have worked more in its favor.

Then there are other things in-game that need clean up. The spell book for instance is disorganized listing the spells in order you learned them vs alphabetically or by spell type. In fact, some of the spell descriptions need to be revised for the simple fact none of them tell you who or what it targets. Then there are also redundant spells that are slightly more powerful versions of what you already have. Would've been great if they kept it to a single spell but added a new power level to it in order to decrease disorganized clutter, but whatever.

I bought this game on sale with all its DLC for $6 and pocket change, and I don't feel it was worth it. Not recommended at all.

reviewText: Being a fan of turn based strategy - and still trying to find something which recreates the atmosphere of Master of Magic - I really wanted this to work.  The combat aspect does but the problem is there actually seems to be so little else.  There's nothing wrong with combat in an empire building game, of course, but the lack of other gameplay dimensions just leave MoA feeling rather unsatisfactory.  With their being few options to win other than destroying - or at least dominating - the opposition alliances seem rather pointless, rather too obvious examples of marriages of convenience.  Focus is so much on the 'home world', units continuously fed and gobbled up into the unending battle, that diverting resources to the alternative worlds is wasteful.  Any serious attempt to move into such worlds requires such numbers that it inevitably leaves the flank of the home world vulnerable, often ensuring defeat.  Sadly, this leaves the additional worlds feeling irrelevant and gimicky, as oppose to the desperately essential New World fat with resources Myrimor felt like in MoM.  There seem to be rather rudimentary omissions too - after all my hours my victory is greated with a rather underwhelming still; there is no leaderboard to record the same after the disappointing image; there are no steam achievements; the choice of wizards somehow lack personality.  It's seem polished at first, but somehow a bit by-the-numbers and rather unfulfilling.  Shame - really wanted just a bit more, but the search continues...

A surprising gem!  I got this as part of a bundle without knowing anything about it at all, and was pleasantly surprised.  It's a hex-based strategy game which is realtively light, and whose mechanics keep it tight the whole way through.  The gameplay is sort of like Civilization 5 minus Civilization 4 - city building and resources are dealt with in a minimalist style, and the hex-based combat has a similar feel to the best of Civ 5, with an expanded system for damage types.  It also has an overland magic system that will remind you of Master of Magic.  Apart from tight mechanics, this game is also very colourful - visually appealing with an entertaining roster of units, and a sense of humour which isn't forced or overlaboured.  The only real downside is that the animations are too long, and you need to skip them to play at any rate - doubly bad as that detracts from the atmosphere and also gives you RSI.  Would still strongly recommend if you're looking for a combat focused turn-based strategy game that's a bit more lightweight than other games in the genre.

Its hard not to compare this game to Civilization 5 and the ever so many games that look similar in this genre, but this game stands out like a wolf in a hen-house.

Warlock master of the arcane strikes at you in much the same manner as being seduced by Scarlett Johansen (whom has for mysterious reasons never actually seduced me), It has a wonderful combination of deep tactical descicion-making, a wonderful sense of humor that isn't scared of mocking itself combined with the estetics you'd expect of any such game. If I was to point out a single flaw it would be the strategy level of things which is to be considered ''light'', as diplomacy, city management and internal governing is rather streamlined and simplified but this  would depend greatly on a player's taste.

It is a fantastic game that keeps suprising you, keeps you interested in its late game and seemingly never runs out of things to do! Quite frankly this game is in my opinion the definition of making a great game rather then a game made to please as many people as possible for better sales numbers.

Anybody remember Master of Magic? Warlock isn't an entirely faithful remake but as the subtitle suggests it definitely takes a lot of inspiration from it, marrying Civ-style empire building with fantasy concepts and most importantly magic, right down to spells that can change terrain types, summon powerful units or place permanent enhancements on units.

The game is well-balanced and allows for enough diversity in approach to offer good replay value. It's solidly constructed but maybe a bit too shallow for diehard strategy fans. The GUI can be a bit iffy at times, getting you stuck on screens without discernible exit, but hitting ESC usually solves that problem. Considering the price tag that's not even an issue however.

Beyond the magical elements it squarely falls on the Civ side of strategy games, omitting detailed battles for simple unit vs. unit square-offs on the world map. Anyone who enjoys any kind of Civ game and is looking for something less complex they can finish inside of a few hours should be delighted to have this game. Anyone who likes fantasy themes and is looking for something with a bit of strategical meat to it (where games such as Heroes VI or King's Bounty are mostly governed by tactical rather than strategical choices) should be equally happy.

And lasty there's the humor. The game doesn't take itself or its setting all too seriously which helps keep the experience light. I still chuckle every time an archer hero yells out 'SPROING' when attacking an enemy.

I had high hopes for this game. I thought it might be somewhat similar to XCOM, which was my first foray into turn-based strategy games. No such luck. Warlock - Master of the Arcane has no story, clunky controls, annoying voice-overs, cliche lore, and is painfully sexist. There is apparently no real campaign, just quests that randomly appear. The controls work some of the time, and there is no menu to map controls to different keys. The voice acting is stilted at best, and tends to be jarring. Play is slow and uninteresting. Out of all the character options (~12) there are two females - a healer and a dragon queen. There's no female undead character, or a female battle-mage, which was extremely disappointing. The only redeeming qualities? Well, the graphics are nice enough, but the best thing is I got this for free in a humble bundle, so I can throw this abysmal excuse for a strategy game away with no regrets.\n2/10

Basically, it's Civ 5 meets Master of Magic. If you like either of those, give it a shot. It is shorter on variety and gets too easy in the late game, but still a lot of fun.

On one hand, you could call this game fantasy Civ V and leave it at that. And you'd be pretty accurate.

On the other, you could call it a surprisingly deep and funny hex-based grand strategy game with clever tongue-in-cheek flavor text and voicing to back up a fast-paced, engaging, and interesting gameplay that will always leave you with plenty on your plate to work on and plenty to look forward to until the moment you win.

You will probably never run out of world to explore, even after searching most of the primary map, since the best resources are off in the distance, hiding, and the alternate worlds have even better loot to find, and you will probably never be able to dedicate as much of your resources as you'd like to exploring, because there are always monsters or angy neighbors on your doorstep just waiting to punch you in the face when you aren't looking.

While it puts just a little much value in the city-spam, Warlock is a fiendishly fun and interesting game that is yes, like Civ, but also independent of it in character and style. And is extremely fun.

If you like turn based 4X and fantasy this is a pretty fun game to dump some time into.  It shares some elements with Civ5, Heroes of Might and Magic and of course Majesty.  Diplomacy is a little lacking and schizophrenic so it's really war heavy, I've found it necessary to constantly sign and resign non-aggression pacts in order to stay at peace when my army's busy clearing another realm for expansion.   The spellcasting is a really neat element though and a lot of fun to play with especially the terraforming spells.  Need a land bridge between continents?  Raise one.  Farms not producing in your frozen tundra?  Make the land fertile.  Don't be afraid to enchant away either, the upkeep really isn't bad considering how much mana you eventually bring in.  The difficulty is a little on the weak side though and once you get the hang of the mechanics  it's not really challenging in the long run, then again that's a problem most 4X games have so I wouldn't let that influence things much.

To conquer the lands as your chosen lord, leading your armies to conquest.\n\nYou can play a variety of races, from the usual humans to bestial creatures to undead, while being able to use each one's skill to however your preferences are. After gaining enough experience with a unit, the option will be given to promote their abilities at random. This, along with the random spells you get help to make the game interesting. Sound: Great sound. From great music to units shouting out battle crys before attacking. Spell sounds are also done well too. Voice acting is also pretty good. 10/10

Story: Really, it's a 4X strategy game (amuch like civilization 5) so there isn't really a story-line here. But because it's a 4X it doesn't need it. But this game goes further and puts in a bunch of lore for each unit, resource, and great mage there is the game, which is always a plus. 9/10

Gameplay: If you like Civ 5, your gonna like this. It's basically that with a high focus on a Fantasy setting, which I personally love. But there some changes though. This game gives you full customization of your world as well as your Great mage from the start, which is always nice. And, probabbly the game's biggest selling point, it has a HUGE unit variety. Even units that aren't appart to your Mage's race can be used by capturing one of their cities. This makes for some awesome mixed armies. There isn't technologies anymore though, instead there are spells, which I thought was a good change. These spells range from summons to buffs, attacks to heals, and even let you alter the land itself. However there is one major flaw I see. ALL of the game's victory conditions are basically militaristic one way or another. This makes Diplomacy seem like a very small edition that you really don't have to worry about. And Diplomacy itself is very basic. Now, I'm sure the Developers purposly did this due to large amount of units, but it really just limits the game. 8.5/10

Replayability: Like I said, High Unit amount. 3 different races of monsters, as well as some special creatures. However, due to the extremely similar victory conditions, it takes away from the replayability. 7/10

Last thoughts: I loved Warlock. Sure Diplomacy is mostly pointless and late game can get kinda tediouse (but this is apparent in most 4X titles) and the victory conditions may be very similar, but that doesn't stop this from being a great title. If you like 4X Strategy games. Buy it. Like Civ 5? Buy it. Like Fantasy Strategy Games? Buy it. Theres even a demo if your unsure. my thoughts on the sequel. Don't but it. Just buy this game with all the expansions and you basically have the sequal.

This game can't avoid comparisons to Civ, so let's look at the differences.

Warlock:
* Is more focused on magical/fantasy units
* Has hireable champions, after a fashion (Lords)
* Has more varied NPC enemies and cities
* Has enemy player AI that will actually ally up with you (revolutionary, compared to Civ V's broken diplomacy)
* Has quests that feel impactful, opposed to Civ's city-state questing
* Has no focus on city production; buildings and units happen in an orderly queue that's only ever several turns deep

Downsides to Warlock:
* Unit selection feels a little sticky, de-selecting isn't all that fluid (Civ also has this problem)
* The game's a bit of a resource pig (try typing in another window while it's up)
* There is nearly nothing by way of a tutorial, so get ready for reading up on forums to learn about Religions and the like

This game is worth a play through and is probably a good pickup for strategy fans if it's in the sub-$15 range. Replay value is moderately high.

Sooo... This game is a simplistic, fantasy themed Civ V.

Nah really that's it. There's not much happening here. There are three resources to manage, three different races to play, you can kind of choose different 'civ leaders' to play but you can edit them easily because they're literally a few buffs for resource gathering and a few staring spells, you have a bunch of units whose stats are pretty straight forward and you can improve them but they don't really 'advance' other than leveling up and building improvements, your civ researches are replaced with researching new spells, there are neutral 'city-states' that you can fight and take over because there's no diplomatic options with them, there are monsters you can murder, and there are multiple worlds that function somewhat similar to the one you start on but tend to have more and higher level monsters.

That's everything. That's all the game's features, right there. I might have missed one or two things but there's just not much to 'get' from this game. There isn't even a campaign, it's just skirmish or multiplayer. Having played other turn based strategy games, this one seems like it would be good for someone who's never played one before.

That said, it's not bad. Everything in it is functional. You do have to have graphical options above a certain point or a lot of the game's UI features don't work, at least for me, but really it's not terribly intensive even on the higher settings.

If you like turn based strategy and fantasy, this is okay. It does a lot of macro-level controls very well. If you want very precise control, or even a lot of things to manage in your turn based strategy game or, I dunno, a lot of options for things you'll probably want to find something else.

absolutely amazing. But, let's go into detail as to why.
Setting: A high-fantasy setting with dragons and mages and gods and stuff. (If you couldn't figure that out by the title, I feel sorry for you.)
Who you play as: A master ritualist, who is able to cast spells clear across the world. You control mass armies with absolutely no minds of their own. (as standard for 4X games)
Now to the jucy stuff.
How optimized is it? To give you a good idea: I bought a 300 dollar laptop to be nothing but a virus-free stock trading machine, with almost no GPU or CPU power. Runs it just fine. A tad slow, but still runs fine. There is a point here, though, that I MUST  point out. You can NOT turn off animation, by what I can tell. And just about everything has god damned animations. Don't get me wrong they look really nice, and they are well-optimized...but if you could disable the animation, you could probably use a $100 laptop from 8-9 years ago to run this game. Animations, especially for a lot of simultaneous units costs quite a large deal of power.
Research is not for typical technology. In fact, technology is not dependent upon research at all. Instead, it's determined by your buildings, which is somewhat odd...yet neat at the same time. Now, what your research IS for: new spells and rituals which you can then cast to either plague your enemy or grant boons to your allies.
How is research done? Well, kinda standard: you select what you want to research, then wait for a set amount of time based on points required / points generated per turn. But, unlike most games which have specific tech trees, the spells you get the chance to research are relatively randomly picked, and you get a selection of 5. I think there are some basic requirements before it is in the pool of potential spells, as I never had a top-tier spell show up early on, but I did get like a lesser and a greater version of the same spell in the spell research at the same time.
How's the unit selection? Well, it's damn good. Took me a good several games to play most of them, and even now, after 47.3 hours, I've yet to use some, or have them used on me (most notably the incredibly expensive dragon...which takes so long to build, and save up for, it's pretty much not worth it). There are some slightly unbalanced units, at least for their cost, but it's nothing gamebreaking, and even old trolls can be killed quite handily.
There are also champions, or basically super minions that must be bought when they randomly appear. This comes from one of the DLC, and REALLY seems like an after-thought more than anything. Some are just not good for their cost, others are quite insane, and snowball so extremely that they single-handedly decimate armies and take entire towns in one shot. Now, several heroes can EVENTUALLY do that, but of course, some are just overpowered, and ramp up far too quickly.
Not to mention the only way to attract them is to wait for the RNG to give you the chance to buy them. There is NO way to influence this by my experience. This is a particularly dissapointing part of the game, but, I think the other, more polished features make up for this.
Graphics: I really can not comment too greatly on this, as I am no graphic critic, but they looked pretty nice. I also liked the graphic style, but that is nothing mut personal preference.
AI: Can be quite punishing. I, however, was never really at any risk of losing...aside from at the very beginning...from an AI. But, they do have no problems with taking your undefended, and lightly-defended cities. The diplomacy system, however, is kinda weak, and kinda lacks a bit of the personality you would like, but it's...robust. It works. You, however, can force someone to bribe you for peace, then just continue to conquer them. I am actually ok with that, but the AI never learns that you do this, so they will keep giving you money to continue your conquest.

Maps: there are several parts that make a good map, in my opinion, so I will split this up.
Variety: Each map is randomly generated. So yes, it's got a good deal of variety (Screw spelling). There are also a nice, large number of different types fo tiles, and their art work is not wholely independent of eachother. If a plains is by a lava field, the lava art will leak over into the near-by tiles without changing the tile itself. Just look at the screenshots for exampls of this.
Shape of tiles: Hexagonal tiles are always the best. It will always take the same number of movements to move from one tile to another, so long as you go directly there, regardless of moving diagonally or up then right or left.
How easily can you tell the terrain types apart? Incredibly easily. A swamp looks nothing like a volcano or ocean, a plains looks nothing like frozen terrain. You can easily tell when tiles are seperated by rivers.

This game gets a 10/10 from me. It's basically Civilization V... but with MAGIC... dragons, gods, mythology, wizards, and monsters. Need I say more? Well here's more:
-The graphics... holy cow the fidelity! So vivid, lush and vibrant! Some of the most beautiful environments I have ever seen. Care was even placed into animating city borders. Everything comes together to seriously make you feels that the world you're playing in is filled with magic.
-The combat in this game completely blows the Civ5 combat system out of the water. Your units can continue leveling indefinitely and gain permanent buffs from the spells you cast upon them. As a result you end up caring about your units and start to grow with them through the ages. They each become quite formidable in their own right. That archer you started out with on turn 1? Well guess what, he's fighting an immortal god now on turn 80 because you kept investing in him.
-There are randomly generating events happening all over the world that affects all players, which is absolutely awesome. You're fighting not just on land and sea but in other dimensions and planetary planes. There is also huge replay ability through the randomly generated maps, and the versatility in which you can play your wizard. Do you want to create the most powerful cities the world has ever seen? Or do you want your units to take on gods? Or would you rather amass the greatest army or navy? Or just burn everyone with your magic!
-The units you can build are based upon your environment... that's right... you can potentially get different types of armies every game! You are no longer tied down to your race or class but can scour the world seeking elves, werewolf, or dragon turtles.
-The interface looks absolutely breath taking. Someone put a lot of love and care into designing an extremely immersive interface.

Cons:
-Unit controls and deselection sometimes executes commands you did not intend.
-There is no visible tech tree for spells, which I'd imagine is quite extensive, you end up praying for the spell you want.
It's alright, but the annoying Sean Connery advisor will kind of make you want to strangle him from time to time.

At first glance, Warlock looks like a Civilization clone but this wizard has quite a few tricks up his sleeve. Customizeable mages, an interesting religion system, and upgradeable units make this a great turn based strategy game, harkening back to the Might and Magic games of old.

Like Civ 4 and/or 5?  A fan of traditional fantasy settings and overly powerful magic spells?  Want to mix the two?  Warlock is just that.

The setting is based on the Majesty universe: all the typical fantasy tropes (humans, undead, dwarves, elves, dragons, trolls, etc, etc in a medieval time period) with a lighter (less doom and gloom, more tongue-in-cheek) feel.  The gameplay is mostly Civ, but with a few twists.  Build progressions for cities feel like a good mix between Civ and the Majesty world, and the tech tree is replaced by a progressive magic research tree.  Want the best units?  Rather than relying upon long term tech research, powerful units are acquired through hired or captured heroes and specific city building dependencies.  Research is still a big part of the game, but it instead leads to more powerful spells that you cast to effect the world directly: heal, destroy, buff or curse units, terraform land, bless your cities, etc.

While I was never personally a fan of Civ's barbarian AI (frequently capable of screwing players randomly early on, never relevant in later game), Warlock really improves upon the typical barbarian" elements and adds a more RPG feel with interest and depth to the later game and a better balance early on. reviewText: This is an ambitious game that's pretty well-made, but ultimately is just very...middling. It's a very combat-focused 4X game, but since everything is for the ultimate goal of combat, it ends up feeling very narrow. The world has lots of NPC monsters that create a cool world, but they quickly become just background annoyances that you have to spend resources to control.\n\nTo be fair, I only got about two hours into a game after playing the demo several times, so maybe it gets way more interesting later on (for instance, I barely got to explore through any of the portals), but I just got bored and didn't want to see any more. If the demo REALLY grabs you, you may also like the main game, but otherwise, I'd go elsewhere for your 4X strategy fix.

A surprising gem!  I got this as part of a bundle without knowing anything about it at all, and was pleasantly surprised.  It's a hex-based strategy game which is realtively light, and whose mechanics keep it tight the whole way through.  The gameplay is sort of like Civilization 5 minus Civilization 4 - city building and resources are dealt with in a minimalist style, and the hex-based combat has a similar feel to the best of Civ 5, with an expanded system for damage types.  It also has an overland magic system that will remind you of Master of Magic.  Apart from tight mechanics, this game is also very colourful - visually appealing with an entertaining roster of units, and a sense of humour which isn't forced or overlaboured.  The only real downside is that the animations are too long, and you need to skip them to play at any rate - doubly bad as that detracts from the atmosphere and also gives you RSI.  Would still strongly recommend if you're looking for a combat focused turn-based strategy game that's a bit more lightweight than other games in the genre.

Either way: it looks good, doesn't lag when things get huge, and it has this VERY interesting mechanic of other worlds": portals leading to maps within maps that I think bring a new and interesting aspect to an otherwise bland cut and paste copy of a Civs game."

absolutely amazing. But, let's go into detail as to why.
Setting: A high-fantasy setting with dragons and mages and gods and stuff. (If you couldn't figure that out by the title, I feel sorry for you.)
Who you play as: A master ritualist, who is able to cast spells clear across the world. You control mass armies with absolutely no minds of their own. (as standard for 4X games)
Now to the jucy stuff.
How optimized is it? To give you a good idea: I bought a 300 dollar laptop to be nothing but a virus-free stock trading machine, with almost no GPU or CPU power. Runs it just fine. A tad slow, but still runs fine. There is a point here, though, that I MUST  point out. You can NOT turn off animation, by what I can tell. And just about everything has god damned animations. Don't get me wrong they look really nice, and they are well-optimized...but if you could disable the animation, you could probably use a $100 laptop from 8-9 years ago to run this game. Animations, especially for a lot of simultaneous units costs quite a large deal of power.
Research is not for typical technology. In fact, technology is not dependent upon research at all. Instead, it's determined by your buildings, which is somewhat odd...yet neat at the same time. Now, what your research IS for: new spells and rituals which you can then cast to either plague your enemy or grant boons to your allies.
How is research done? Well, kinda standard: you select what you want to research, then wait for a set amount of time based on points required / points generated per turn. But, unlike most games which have specific tech trees, the spells you get the chance to research are relatively randomly picked, and you get a selection of 5. I think there are some basic requirements before it is in the pool of potential spells, as I never had a top-tier spell show up early on, but I did get like a lesser and a greater version of the same spell in the spell research at the same time.
How's the unit selection? Well, it's damn good. Took me a good several games to play most of them, and even now, after 47.3 hours, I've yet to use some, or have them used on me (most notably the incredibly expensive dragon...which takes so long to build, and save up for, it's pretty much not worth it). There are some slightly unbalanced units, at least for their cost, but it's nothing gamebreaking, and even old trolls can be killed quite handily.
There are also champions, or basically super minions that must be bought when they randomly appear. This comes from one of the DLC, and REALLY seems like an after-thought more than anything. Some are just not good for their cost, others are quite insane, and snowball so extremely that they single-handedly decimate armies and take entire towns in one shot. Now, several heroes can EVENTUALLY do that, but of course, some are just overpowered, and ramp up far too quickly.
Not to mention the only way to attract them is to wait for the RNG to give you the chance to buy them. There is NO way to influence this by my experience. This is a particularly dissapointing part of the game, but, I think the other, more polished features make up for this.
Graphics: I really can not comment too greatly on this, as I am no graphic critic, but they looked pretty nice. I also liked the graphic style, but that is nothing mut personal preference.
AI: Can be quite punishing. I, however, was never really at any risk of losing...aside from at the very beginning...from an AI. But, they do have no problems with taking your undefended, and lightly-defended cities. The diplomacy system, however, is kinda weak, and kinda lacks a bit of the personality you would like, but it's...robust. It works. You, however, can force someone to bribe you for peace, then just continue to conquer them. I am actually ok with that, but the AI never learns that you do this, so they will keep giving you money to continue your conquest.

Maps: there are several parts that make a good map, in my opinion, so I will split this up.
Variety: Each map is randomly generated. So yes, it's got a good deal of variety (Screw spelling). There are also a nice, large number of different types fo tiles, and their art work is not wholely independent of eachother. If a plains is by a lava field, the lava art will leak over into the near-by tiles without changing the tile itself. Just look at the screenshots for exampls of this.
Shape of tiles: Hexagonal tiles are always the best. It will always take the same number of movements to move from one tile to another, so long as you go directly there, regardless of moving diagonally or up then right or left.
How easily can you tell the terrain types apart? Incredibly easily. A swamp looks nothing like a volcano or ocean, a plains looks nothing like frozen terrain. You can easily tell when tiles are seperated by rivers.

Better than any Civilization game.

The combat mechanics are explicitly exposed: Units do some amount of damage, which is partially mitigated by various resistances. Targetting the weakest resistance is a big part of being successful in combat. However, you can't just pile on resistances; you get diminishing returns, so you will always take -some- damage from a powerful attack.

Units can't stack, either. There's none of the Civ-style nonsense where 1 low-tech unit can indefinitely fend off mountains of high-tech units (1 pikeman vs 5 tanks, pikeman wins, gg).

And then you have the spells, which are balanced by how rarely you can cast them. Which spells to cast is a major strategical decision.

I highly recommend it if you like 4X games. The DLC adds interesting things, too.

I LOVE this game. It's the best turn based strategy game I've played in a very long time. Multiple worlds, lots of monsters, diplomacy with other rulers, future DLC and multiplayer on the way and so much more. The fact it's tied into the wondful world of Majesty is just icing on the cake.

I have poured quite a few hours into this game, and I can say that I enjoyed most of it.  It is a 4x hex based game (expand, explore, exterminate, and exploit), akin to Civ 5.  My very limited exposure to Civ 5 leads me to halt any more comparisons there, however I have read there are significant differences between the two games.  I've seen it most compared with Masters of Magic.

The single player can be quite fun due to the interesting characters that exist within the game.  It's also got very solid gameplay and the balance isn't too bad.  The main gripe I've seen about balance is Undead and Favor to Grum-Gog, since it allows the expansion phase to be dominated by the player who chooses it and abuse the fact that Undead don't use food to spam Strong Rats, who use only food as a resource. This can also be abused in multiplayer (which is currently deserted).  Also another gripe I have is the maps are randomly generated, which for the most part is okay, but if I were to take this game super seriously and decide to be competitive, I'd want to be able to make maps to make sure they are well balanced and strategic.

The base game features 3 different races that you can start off with, and each are different enough.  As you take over other towns which belong to a different race than what you start with, you can use their technologies and units to add to your army.  There are dozens of spells that are available that you can use on average once per turn, unless you use a spell that reduces casting time.  The spells range from pure damage to buffs and debuffs to units and global as well as city buffs.  There are also spells you can only get if you worship one of the eight gods, like the Summon Strong Rats I mentioned earlier.

The DLC is decent, one allows you to have hero characters which you can customize with up to three items, one introduces an entire new race, and another allows for a more difficult challenge.  I'd probably get the Armageddon DLC if anything just to make the game a bit more difficult, since the AI's in this game are pretty limited.  The extra race isn't necessary, but it's unique and the hero units are really very strong and can be buffed to ridiculous levels.

Also, before now there was no hope of this game going anywhere.  But there is a new subforum on the official forums for modding.  Before now, Ino-Co or somebody didn't want this to be modded at all, and in turn it pretty much killed the forum community since the game stagnated and there was no more DLC.  Though it looks like that may be reversed soon, which would be way cool.

tl;dr version: 4x game, decent balance, random maps, lots of spells, cool characters, ok DLC, currently no modding, maybe modding later. Good game.
