Great spiritual successor to Master of Magic. The concept is very reminiscent to Civilization although it adds a lot of unique features of its own which creates a really great 4X turn based strategy game set in a fantasy setting.

You control an empire as a wizard, where you conduct research and cast spells, wage war, do diplomacy and develop your infrastructure. You can choose between 3 races that are distinct in their own way and require different playstyles. The maps are varied and filled with loot, monsters and tricky terrain. The AI is also really capable and it can be quite challenging.

The graphics are marvelous for such a game and so is the soundtrack. I definitely recommend this game for anyone who is looking for an experience like Master of Magic or who want to play a game similiar to Civilization but with a fantasy twist.

The only downside that I can think of right now is that there aren't that many factions to choose from and that the map generator can sometimes create really silly maps.

For those looking for game comparisons, it`s probably most similar to a very old game called Master of Magic. It runs on the Civ 5 engine, though, so it`s very pretty. I absolutely recommend this game. It's a lot like Civ 5, but you can actually do things like changing the terrain, attacking with spells, buffing your dudes and so on.

With the Ultimate edition, you have access to 4 races which are fundamentally different. You colonize the world civ-style, but you also have access to other dimensions that you can take over via portals. You can also raise or lower the land level, change the land type, and so on.

The combat aspect is WAY better than in Civ 5, with buffs, debuffs, 5 attack types, 4 unit types (flying, aquatic, amphibious and land) and such.

There is only one majow flaw: There's no hybrid turns in multiplayer. Thus, playing with a lot of people online is not recommended. However, with a small amount of friends and/or AI the game is still a lot of fun.

Like Civ 4 and/or 5?  A fan of traditional fantasy settings and overly powerful magic spells?  Want to mix the two?  Warlock is just that.

The setting is based on the Majesty universe: all the typical fantasy tropes (humans, undead, dwarves, elves, dragons, trolls, etc, etc in a medieval time period) with a lighter (less doom and gloom, more tongue-in-cheek) feel.  The gameplay is mostly Civ, but with a few twists.  Build progressions for cities feel like a good mix between Civ and the Majesty world, and the tech tree is replaced by a progressive magic research tree.  Want the best units?  Rather than relying upon long term tech research, powerful units are acquired through hired or captured heroes and specific city building dependencies.  Research is still a big part of the game, but it instead leads to more powerful spells that you cast to effect the world directly: heal, destroy, buff or curse units, terraform land, bless your cities, etc.

While I was never personally a fan of Civ's barbarian AI (frequently capable of screwing players randomly early on, never relevant in later game), Warlock really improves upon the typical barbarian" elements and adds a more RPG feel with interest and depth to the later game and a better balance early on.  Rather than generic hordes or goodie huts

absolutely amazing. But, let's go into detail as to why.
Setting: A high-fantasy setting with dragons and mages and gods and stuff. (If you couldn't figure that out by the title, I feel sorry for you.)
Who you play as: A master ritualist, who is able to cast spells clear across the world. You control mass armies with absolutely no minds of their own. (as standard for 4X games)
Now to the jucy stuff.
How optimized is it? To give you a good idea: I bought a 300 dollar laptop to be nothing but a virus-free stock trading machine, with almost no GPU or CPU power. Runs it just fine. A tad slow, but still runs fine. There is a point here, though, that I MUST  point out. You can NOT turn off animation, by what I can tell. And just about everything has god damned animations. Don't get me wrong they look really nice, and they are well-optimized...but if you could disable the animation, you could probably use a $100 laptop from 8-9 years ago to run this game. Animations, especially for a lot of simultaneous units costs quite a large deal of power.
Research is not for typical technology. In fact, technology is not dependent upon research at all. Instead, it's determined by your buildings, which is somewhat odd...yet neat at the same time. Now, what your research IS for: new spells and rituals which you can then cast to either plague your enemy or grant boons to your allies.
How is research done? Well, kinda standard: you select what you want to research, then wait for a set amount of time based on points required / points generated per turn. But, unlike most games which have specific tech trees, the spells you get the chance to research are relatively randomly picked, and you get a selection of 5. I think there are some basic requirements before it is in the pool of potential spells, as I never had a top-tier spell show up early on, but I did get like a lesser and a greater version of the same spell in the spell research at the same time.
How's the unit selection? Well, it's damn good. Took me a good several games to play most of them, and even now, after 47.3 hours, I've yet to use some, or have them used on me (most notably the incredibly expensive dragon...which takes so long to build, and save up for, it's pretty much not worth it). There are some slightly unbalanced units, at least for their cost, but it's nothing gamebreaking, and even old trolls can be killed quite handily.
There are also champions, or basically super minions that must be bought when they randomly appear. This comes from one of the DLC, and REALLY seems like an after-thought more than anything. Some are just not good for their cost, others are quite insane, and snowball so extremely that they single-handedly decimate armies and take entire towns in one shot. Now, several heroes can EVENTUALLY do that, but of course, some are just overpowered, and ramp up far too quickly.
Not to mention the only way to attract them is to wait for the RNG to give you the chance to buy them. There is NO way to influence this by my experience. This is a particularly dissapointing part of the game, but, I think the other, more polished features make up for this.
Graphics: I really can not comment too greatly on this, as I am no graphic critic, but they looked pretty nice. I also liked the graphic style, but that is nothing mut personal preference.
AI: Can be quite punishing. I, however, was never really at any risk of losing...aside from at the very beginning...from an AI. But, they do have no problems with taking your undefended, and lightly-defended cities. The diplomacy system, however, is kinda weak, and kinda lacks a bit of the personality you would like, but it's...robust. It works. You, however, can force someone to bribe you for peace, then just continue to conquer them. I am actually ok with that, but the AI never learns that you do this, so they will keep giving you money to continue your conquest.

Maps: there are several parts that make a good map, in my opinion, so I will split this up.
Variety: Each map is randomly generated. So yes, it's got a good deal of variety (Screw spelling). There are also a nice, large number of different types fo tiles, and their art work is not wholely independent of eachother. If a plains is by a lava field, the lava art will leak over into the near-by tiles without changing the tile itself. Just look at the screenshots for exampls of this.
Shape of tiles: Hexagonal tiles are always the best. It will always take the same number of movements to move from one tile to another, so long as you go directly there, regardless of moving diagonally or up then right or left.
How easily can you tell the terrain types apart? Incredibly easily. A swamp looks nothing like a volcano or ocean, a plains looks nothing like frozen terrain. You can easily tell when tiles are seperated by rivers.

A surprising gem!  I got this as part of a bundle without knowing anything about it at all, and was pleasantly surprised.  It's a hex-based strategy game which is realtively light, and whose mechanics keep it tight the whole way through.  The gameplay is sort of like Civilization 5 minus Civilization 4 - city building and resources are dealt with in a minimalist style, and the hex-based combat has a similar feel to the best of Civ 5, with an expanded system for damage types.  It also has an overland magic system that will remind you of Master of Magic.  Apart from tight mechanics, this game is also very colourful - visually appealing with an entertaining roster of units, and a sense of humour which isn't forced or overlaboured.  The only real downside is that the animations are too long, and you need to skip them to play at any rate - doubly bad as that detracts from the atmosphere and also gives you RSI.  Would still strongly recommend if you're looking for a combat focused turn-based strategy game that's a bit more lightweight than other games in the genre.

A combination of Civilization V and Age of Wonders, Warlock: Master of the Arcane is one of the funnest new strategy games I've played in years. The Armageddon game mode is incredibly hard, but beating it was one of the most rewarding strategy accomplishments of my gaming life.

Strengths:
-Great diversity of units, spells, terrain, leaders, etc.
-Clear economy of gold and mana
-Rewarding city management
-Armageddon gamemode

Weaknesses:
-Total lack of building or tech trees, though they can easily be found online
-Low replay value: too easy in any game mode not Armageddon
-Other-world portals can usually be bypassed completely: exploring them, while fun and rewarding, demands too many resources
-Clumsy optimization, even on a middling graphics card

Overall: 7/10

A solid fantasy 4X using hexes and one unit per tile, but with some issues.

The interference occasionally has issues, like not centring on selected units. The magic system isn't great and the casting times make it a lot of hassle to use all the low impact spells that would be optimal. The religion system offers all the specialized spells, and can be very important for elite units depending on race and resources, but doesn't work well either, you gain favour by having expensive starting perks, randomly getting a quest that is completable or finding one of the rare and defended holy grounds (in my first game I found none of them for ages and wondered how I was meant to complete the quests to make temples I kept getting and losing favour as I failed). Water units are also lacking, with very little varity or ways to upgrade compared to land. I found games becoming a hassle and the AI stopping being a threat late on, and had the shrink down the worlds and factions generated to make things quicker.

Despite that nitpicking it is an engrossing 4x, managing the one-more-turn compulsion. I've already played a lot and enjoyed it, without even touching multiplayer or the apocalypse mode.

Master of Magic meets Civilization 5 and the result is pretty good. There is some problems with details, but overall it works. I'm going to make a lot of references to Master of Magic (MoM) because I love that 20 years old game and this one reminds me of it in a good way. For example:
The research system is reserved to spells, but there is a tech tree of sorts to the units too: In order to build units you need buildings and more advanced buildings for more advanced units. To build the advanced buildings you need to have the basic buildings first. The difference to MoM is that the buildings occupy hexes and there isn't necessarily room to build everything... until you learn the landscaping spells to make more room, that is.
MoM had the other world besides the main map: Myrror. In this game there can be several alternate worlds, though they are smaller than the main map. They are not as developed as Myrror, only filled with dangerous monsters. Also there seems to be only one portal to each, which could be a bottleneck.
The different races with unique buildings and units, though this game has only 4, while MoM had 14.This game also adds to the mix a parthenon of deities, which is a pretty standard thing in fantasy literature, but usually missing in these games. There are divine spells, which are mostly slightly powerful or a bit easier to cast versions of regular spells, that you can only research and cast if you are in favor of that deity. You can gain favor by doing quests and building temples on the holy ground. While you bow down to one god, you show your backside the opposite god. One way to win the game is to get one god so angry that it manifests on the map and then destroy it. Religion also affects the relationships between the wizards. It's a nice system.

Speaking of quests, they kind of suck. You just get some random build this building/found a city/kill these random enemies that popped up here/capture this city/defeat this player that just pops up. Same with random events being just monster lairs popping up on your lands. Definitely the weakest part of this game. MoM's events had much more style. Some might argue that the AI not being able to handle the complexities could be a bigger problem. I didn't play enough to be sure, but it seemed to be struggling with it. Not worse than Civ 5, but in this game it has to handle with the parallel worlds, terrain changing by spells and stuff like that too.

All in all a very nice concept that could use some tweaking and filling out the content to be really great. I'm glad I got this free from Humble Bundle. Made me put Warlock II high on my wishlist.

This game is very challenging.

I would classify it as a 4X game, so you know that as you play each turn, each successive turn starts to take longer and longer because you've got more and more cities.

Does it scratch the strategy itch? Sort of, but not really. There are a few different strategy elements which are mildly interesting. First, you've got your cities. Each city can have buildings, each of which have different bonuses. You have to manage your mana, food, gold, research, and unit production. The trick is to just build cities and focus them on just one resource (to max out your bonuses).

The second strategy layer is the units and combat. You've got melee units, ranged units, and AoE variants of the two. The general strategy is to have your melee units in front and your ranged units in the back, and try to kill the enemy units faster than they can make them. You also get hero characters, which, with careful management, can become very over powered. In fact, the focus of the game trends towards trying to keep your heros alive as long as possible.

Just to keep you on your toes, the game randomly spawns lots of monsters of a random type every 30 turns or so. It is more of a nuisance than anything else.

The AI and diplomacy is absurdly simplistic though, so that's quite a fault of this game. You pretty much have four possible relationships: War, rivals, peace, allies. In terms of diplomacy, the only purpose is to turn an AI player into your friend to keep them off your back while you fight some other AI player. Inevitably, each AI player will declare war on you, so don't bother trying to build any sort of close relationship.

Is the game fun? Sure, I enjoy it. I can easily lose track of time playing this game.

Is the game *interesting*? Not really. The mechanics are just too simplistic to give the game long term interest. There's just not a lot of versatility, so the replayability suffers quite a bit once you've got it figured out.

Should you get it? If you've played every other 4X fantasy strategy game out there, this one just promises to deliver more of the same with some variations to the flavor.

This one positively surprised me. Got this for free during the Humble Bundle thing and had a great time with it ever since. Warlock - Master of the Arcane is a turn based strategy game about a warlock (surprise, surprise!) battling his colleagues in an epic battle for a world filled with Gods, parallel worlds, and more monsters than you can count. The game itself shows a clear influence from the Age of Wonders series. Research spells and unleash them to grant your troops new abilities, weaken and damage your enemies, or change the face of the world around you. Water blocking your way? Raise the land and create a passage for your troops that doesn't put them at the mercy of naval monsters! Mountains slowing down your troops? Flatten them. The mountains, not the troops. Just make sure you have the mana to sustain all your permanent spells. There is little as terrifying as a flying ogre with a vampiric regeneration and an area attack.

Mana, as well as gold and food (your main resources) are generated by city buildings. You can found or capture cities, although make sure they have enough room to grow. Place them near strategic resources for some special buildings, depending on the faction that lives in your city - the undead will utilise a pumkin patch different than humans would. Depending on which buildings you have, you can purchase powerful upgrades for your troops, ranging from a slight defense bonus to health regeneration each turn. They will also gain experience from battles, and you may choose an improvement with every levelup as well.

Battles are fairly simple. Move your troops on the hex of the enemy you wish to attack, and they automatically fight. Damage is determined by the health of your troops (full health = max strength), as well as their damage type and the enemy defense. Heroes on either side, like the aforementioned flying ogre, might turn the tide of a battle, and placing your troops in cities or on mountains might give you the edge you need. Randomly given quests by Gods, guilds or an advisor will offer you some short to middle term objectives and keep you busy for a bit, as you wouldn't want to anger a God. Especially the Divine missions often offer a great reward as well, be it a spell or a troop tied to that particular deity. You wouldn't want to miss out on those now, would you?

All in all a great game with a lot of unit variety, customiseability and a weird sense of humour. One minor issue, though... please don't use Google Translator for in game text. I originally installed the german version, and promptly found some rather glaring issues with that (Close was basically translated to 'near city view' as opposed to 'close that window', for example). Luckily, Steam allowed me to easily switch to english.
